NEW YORK,.March 29, 1927
ANNA MAHON.
TYPES OF HEROES.
div1.p:
Flags and bunting flying in the breeze, whistles blowing,
sirens screaching, bells ringing, and crowds of people lined up on
both sides of the avenue as far as eye can see. A sudden quiet
seems to have fallen on the surging mob, but it is the lull that
precedes the storm. Coming slowly up the avenue, preceded by a
joyous band, comes a man. The storm breaks - a mighty shout is
heard, cheers rend the air and hats and handkerchiefs wave on
every side - a wild demonstration of joy for a Hero has just
passed by! What mighty deed of valor had he done? What courage
and fortitude had he displayed in time of danger? What act of
heroism had he performed to warrant this manifestation of approbation
by an appreciative and admiring public? Without doubt, his act
included all the requisites necessary to entitle him to the renown
and honor thus afforded him.

Situated on the South Sea Island is a place called Molokai.
To this Island in the year 1873, came a young Catholic priest by the
name of Father Damien. A more wretched, desolate, miserable place
than this island it would be hard to find. It was the home, refuge
of the lepers. Father Damien, a fearless Belgian priest, filled
with Divine love for God and for his fellow man, when the call for
service came, studied medicine in the best universities in Europe.
He specialized in skin diseases and then, equipped to give his services

as priest and physician, separated himself from those near and dear
to him, and spent his life among these poor outcasts. After ten years
of unmitigated toil and earnest zeal to benefit this exiled leper colony,
he contracted the fatal malady and died in his fiftieth year. Courage,
fortitude, valor, self-renunication and nobility of soul were the
attributes necessary for his heroic sacrifice. He gave his life that
others might live. He laid down his life for his fellow man. His was
the supreme test of heroism, and he met it unflinchingly. Truly we may
say that a hero has passed by.

In the throngs that daily walk the busy streets in every city,
large or small, we meet another type of heroism. It is composed of
the vast army of plain every day people. These go about their every
day duties, and from outward appearance all seems well. But who can
tell the anguish of mind and anxiety of soul or the trials and suffer-
ings that they are called upon to witness and endure? Some of us go
through life oppressed by a burden that constantly weighs us down and
which, at times, seems almost beyond our endurance. Does it not
require courage, pluck, bravery, and often self-renunciation to meet
these conditions and make us shoulder our burdens and carry on the
battle of life which ends only in the grave? Would it not be unfair
to place these brave, obscure, unknown, unhonored and unrenowned
persons in any but the hero class? Are they not also Heroes passing by?

Therefore, in conclusion, whether we consider the home-coming

hero, joyously welcomed by the city, or the martyr hero dying far
from home for a Cause, or the humble silent hero assuming another's
heavy cross and bearing it uncomplainingly, we are confronted with
the fact that in every particular instance the identical attributes
of heroism were essential. Each in his own way is a hero. Each
particular type is to some few, a hero. But may we say in God's
sight, “Heroes All”.
